newsitem.title: TAIWAN: TAIWAN CABINET APPROVES TAX MERGER PROPOSAL.
newsitem.headline: TAIWAN CABINET APPROVES TAX MERGER PROPOSAL.

text.p: Taiwan's cabinet on Thursday approved a tax merger proposal to boost investment which has been slowing, officials said.
"The cabinet agreed to merge the island's two income taxes into one business income tax and set the merged rate at 25 percent," a government spokesman said.
The proposal was initiated by the finance ministry in October 1996.

The merger would reduce tax revenues by about T$30-40 billion a year, but the finance ministry would recoup the sharp downturn by assessing a 10 percent levy on profits that enterprises reserve rather than distribute to shareholders immediately, officials said.
The new tax system would avoid double taxation and will help corporate structures, finance minister Paul Chiu had said.
"In fact this is a tax reduction," Chiu said. "It will encourage investment (in Taiwan) and increase our international competitiveness."

Taiwan has been trying to entice major multinationals to locate their Asia-Pacific operations centres to the island by boosting local economic competitiveness, but the scheme has been hindered by the slow pace of market liberalisation, including tax reform.
The tax revision still needs final approval by the parliament and could take effect in January 1998 if all goes well.
Foreign nationals' taxes would not be affected and their maximum rate would remain at 40 percent, Chiu said.
The tax merger is really an accounting change that eliminates double taxation of companies' profits and the dividends they pay to shareholders, analysts said.
As a result, the maximum assessment on domestic individuals' income will be capped at 40 percent, below the maximum level of 55 percent for which they were liable before the merger.
Currently, foreign investors' income is taxed first by a 25 percent business income tax, and then a 20 percent dividend tax on the 75 percent untaxed part, making the rate 40 percent.
